question: You are hooking a tractor to a semi-trailer and have backed up but are not yet under it. What should you do before backing under the trailer?
options: Hook up the electrical service cable
Hook up the emergency and service air lines
Connect the ground cable
Nothing — back up and secure the fifth wheel to the trailer

question: After pushing in the trailer supply valve, you should not move the tractor until the whole system is:
options: Charging
At normal pressure
Bled down to half the maximum pressure
Between 50 and 60 psi

question: There are two things that a driver can do to prevent a rollover. They are (1) keep the cargo as close to the ground as possible, and:
options: Make sure the brakes are adjusted properly
Keep both hands on the steering wheel
Drive slowly around turns
Keep the fifth wheel free-play loose

question: When pulling a trailer, you should:
options: Make sudden movements with the steering wheel
Steer gently and smoothly
Slow down to a safe speed after entering a turn
All of the above

question: The fifth wheel locking lever is not locked after the jaws close around the kingpin. This means that:
options: The trailer will not swing on the fifth wheel
You cannot set the fifth wheel for proper weight distribution
The hand valve is released and you may drive away
The coupling is not correct and should be corrected before driving the coupled unit

question: A driver crosses the air lines when hooking up to an old trailer. What will happen?
options: The hand valve will apply the tractor brakes instead of the trailer brakes
The brake pedal will work the trailer spring brakes instead of the trailer service brakes
If the trailer has no spring brakes, the driver could drive away but wouldn’t have trailer brakes
The brake lights will not come on when the brake pedal is pressed

question: After coupling a semi-trailer, how should you crank up the front trailer supports (dollies)?
options: Raised halfway with the crank handle secured
Raised halfway with the crank handle removed
Fully raised with the crank handle secured
Three turns off the top with the crank handle secured in its bracket

question: Air brake equipped trailers made before 1975:
options: Are not required to have spring brakes
Are easier to stop than newer trailers because they are heavier
Usually need a glad hand converter
Cannot be operated on interstate highways

question: The hand valve should only be used:
options: When you park at loading docks
When you are parking for less than one hour
When parking on a steep grade
To test the trailer brakes

question: Air lines on a combination vehicle are often color-coded to avoid confusion. The emergency line is:
options: Red
Black
Blue
Orange

question: How do you supply air to the air tank on the trailer?
options: Pushing in the trailer air supply knob/valve
Pulling out the trailer air supply knob/valve
Connecting the emergency line glad hand
Applying the trolley valve

question: In normal driving, some drivers use the trolley (hand) valve before the brake pedal. Which of these statements is true?
options: It should never be done
It results in less skidding than using the brake pedal alone
It lets the driver steer with both hands
It is the best way to brake in a straight line

question: When backing under the trailer, you should:
options: Use the lowest reverse gear
Back the tractor slowly under the trailer
Stop when the kingpin is locked into the fifth wheel
All of the above

question: When backing up under a trailer, you should line up:
options: About 15 degrees off the line of the trailer
The right mirror along the right edge of the trailer
Directly in front of the trailer
To the far left of the trailer

question: _______ are coupling devices used to connect the service and emergency air lines from a truck or tractor to the trailer.
options: Clamps
Shut-off valves
Hand valves
Glad hands

question: After hooking up, you should check the fifth wheel connection by:
options: Driving away at 20 mph and pulling down the trailer hand valve
Backing up with the trailer brakes released
Pulling the tractor ahead sharply to release the trailer brakes
Pulling the tractor ahead gently with the trailer brakes locked

question: How often should you drain your vehicle’s trailer air tanks?
options: Daily
Weekly
Monthly
Yearly

question: The emergency air line supplies air to the trailer air tanks and:
options: Supplies air to the cab
Controls the emergency brakes on combination vehicles
Is coded with the color green to keep it from being confused with other lines
All of the above

question: How much space should be between the upper and the lower fifth wheel plates?
options: About 1 inch
About ¾ inch
About ¼ inch
None

question: When not pulling a trailer, why is it a good idea to lock the glad hands together or to a dummy coupler?
options: It keeps air from escaping
The brake circuit becomes a secondary air tank
It keeps dirt and water out of the lines
All of the above
